newsitem.title: ALBANIA: Deported Albanians accuse Italy of cruelty.
newsitem.headline: Deported Albanians accuse Italy of cruelty.

text.p: Albanians deported from Italy after fleeing their troubled homeland accused the Italian authorities on Thursday of treating them like criminals with no concern for their welfare.

Since a wave of violence swept the Balkan nation in March after popular, high-risk savings funds collapsed, 15,387 Albanians have crossed the Adriatic to Italy. Italy has sent back 2,712, mostly young, single men, classed "undesirables".
"Everybody wanted to leave as there is no life for us here," said unemployed bricklayer Engjell Sterkaj, who fled to Italy 10 days ago but was returned within two days.
"But as soon as we arrived we were treated like criminals. Nobody asked us about our problems. We were humiliated."
It is the second recent flood of Albanian refugees into Italy. Thousands fled in 1991 after communism fell.
Passengers pay $500 a head to the organisers of the trips. Trafficking illegal immigrants has become a lucrative business.
But the overcrowding of vessels has had tragic results. Up to 103 Albanians died on March 28 when a packed ship collided with an Italian navy frigate 30 miles off Brindisi and sank.

Sterkaj, 34, was among 571 Albanians crammed onto a fishing boat built for a maximum of 50 that left from Velipoje, 30 kms (20 miles) south of Shkoder in northern Albania, on April 26, arriving at Barletta in southern Italy 27 hours later.
Sterkaj left his wife and two young children at his home in Shkoder, borrowing enough for his own fare on the Miki.
"I wanted to find work in Italy for my family. I have not worked since the pyramid funds collapsed. Everyone lost money and there is no building. Also it is very dangerous," he said.
During riots in early March, state arsenals were looted and armed criminals now roam much of the country. Armed robberies, revenge killings and accidental shootings are daily events.
"The police possess fewer arms than the criminals," Shkoder's major Bahri Barici told Reuters.
"I appeal to countries trying to help Albania to pay more attention to supplying this equipment rather than food aid. We would endure only eating once a day to live in security."
Last weekend, a week after the Miki left, an overcrowded tanker limped from Velipoje to Bari in southern Italy, carrying 1,229 people, many of them women and children.
Most were sent to refugee centres around Italy but up to 200 were immediately repatriated.
Albania's interim prime minister, Bashkim Fino, summoned Italy's ambassador, Paolo Foresti, on Wednesday to convey concerns over repatriations and separating families.
"I asked the Italian government to let Albanians join their families in Italy," Fino told Albanian television.
The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) had recommended Italy allow Albanians to put their cases for protection before acting.
A multinational force, assigned to Albania to oversee aid deliveries, does not have the authority to stop these ships. Spokesmen say its mission is not to act as police.
But securing the main southern ports of Vlore and Durres has effectively blocked such activity and pushed the trafficking of illegal immigrants up to the north coast.
Vasil Marku, a shopkeeper at Velipoje, a dilapidated, former communist holiday resort, said Spanish troops are patrolling the area daily since the last weekend's departure.
A spokesman for the Italian-led force said the patrols were to ensure security in the area for aid distribution.
